qas.question: Which of Claridge's two tar macadams was the more successful?
What world event caused the end of Claridge's company?
What was the subsidiary company that lead Claridge into ruin?
What kind of money did Claridge  invest in attempting  to save his companies?
In what year was the liquidation of the Patent Clarmac Company?
Which company's failure had a flow-over effect on the First World War?

plausible_answers.text: impacted financially on the Clarmac Company

qas.question: What did the Second World War do?
What happened to the Clarmac Company in 1917?
What happened to Claridge's Company in 1915?

context: In 1914, Claridge's Company entered into a joint venture to produce tar-bound macadam, with materials manufactured through a subsidiary company called <a3_0>Clarmac Roads Ltd<a3_0/>. Two products resulted, namely <a0_0>Clarmac<a0_0/>, and Clarphalte, with the former being manufactured by Clarmac Roads and the latter by Claridge's Patent Asphalte Co., although Clarmac was more widely used.[note 1] However, the <a2_0>First World War<a2_0/> <b7_0>impacted financially on the Clarmac Company<b7_0/>, which entered into <b8_0>liquidation<b8_0/> in <a1_0><b5_0>1915<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The failure of <b6_0>Clarmac Roads Ltd<b6_0/> had a flow-on effect to Claridge's Company, which was itself compulsorily wound up, <b9_0>ceasing operations<b9_0/> in 1917, having invested a <a4_0>substantial amount<a4_0/> of funds into the new venture, both at the outset, and in a subsequent attempt to save the Clarmac Company.
